title: EU issues rare interim order against chipmaker Broadcom before completion of probe
text:
Competition commissioner Margrethe Vestager will order the Silicon Valley-based company to stop imposing terms on clients that prevent them from buying chips elsewhere before the commission completes its ongoing probe of the firm. Broadcom will likely appeal the ruling. (Financial Times)

Talking point: This is the competition commission’s first use of an interim order in 18 years—an EU court threw out its previous attempt after the company involved challenged it. If this order holds up in court, EU regulators could use interim measures in the future to go after other tech giants like Google and Facebook. Interim orders require the commission to prove a company’s practices would create lasting damage to competition before an investigation is complete. For instance, a 2010 case in which the commission decided Google illegally favoured its own shopping tool took seven years, during which many rivals left the market. Broadcom hasn’t commented on the ruling, but has previously said that it does not expect such a move to have a material impact on its business.
